=====11 February â Farewell Friday =====
=====11 February â Farewell Friday =====
â
Shock that Mubarak did not step down on Thursday 10 February resulted in a nationwide escalation of protests on 11 February, named "Farewell Friday" by the opposition movement.<ref name="signonsandiego1"/><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Egypt's army vows smooth transition|date=February 12, 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121217639448807.html|accessdate=February 13, 2011}}</ref> Massive protests continued in Cairo, Alexandria, and other cities. The presidential palace and parliament still remained surrounded by protestors and thousands of people surrounded the state TV building, keeping anyone from entering or leaving. The army issued a ''[[communiquÃ©]]'' in support of Mubarak's attempt to remain ''[[de jure]]'' president while delegating his powers to Vice President Suleiman.<ref>{{citation|title=Egyptian army backs Hosni Mubarak and calls for protesters to go home|ell by .25%url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/11/egyptian-army-backs-hosni-mubarak|first=Paul|last=Owen|date=2011/02/11|publisher=Guardian.co.uk}}</ref> Hossam Badrawi, the new secretary of the NDP, resigned from his position from the party due to his unhappiness with Hosni Mubarak's refusal to step down.<ref>[http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/11/latest-updates-on-day-18-of-egypt-protests/?hp "Latest Updates on Day 18 of Egypt Protests"] by Robert Mackey - ''The New York Times.'.' Retrieved 11 February 2011.</ref>{{-}}
+
[[File:Protesters with soldier.jpg|thumb|200px|A soldier joins the protesters in celebration of Mubarak's downfall.]]
  +
Shock that Mubarak did not step down on Thursday 10 February resulted in a nationwide escalation of protests on 11 February, named "Farewell Friday" by the opposition movement.<ref name="signonsandiego1"/><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Egypt's army vows smooth transition|date=February 12, 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121217639448807.html|accessdate=February 13, 2011}}</ref> Massive protests continued in Cairo, Alexandria, and other cities. The presidential palace and parliament still remained surrounded by protestors and thousands of people surrounded the state TV building, keeping anyone from entering or leaving. The army issued a ''[[communiquÃ©]]'' in support of Mubarak's attempt to remain ''[[de jure]]'' president while delegating his powers to Vice President Suleiman.<ref>{{citation|title=Egyptian army backs Hosni Mubarak and calls for protesters to go home|ell by .25%url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/11/egyptian-army-backs-hosni-mubarak|first=Paul|last=Owen|date=2011/02/11|publisher=Guardian.co.uk}}</ref> Hossam Badrawi, the new secretary of the NDP, resigned from his position from the party due to his unhappiness with Hosni Mubarak's refusal to step down.<ref>[http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/11/latest-updates-on-day-18-of-egypt-protests/?hp "Latest Updates on Day 18 of Egypt Protests"] by Robert Mackey - ''The New York Times.'.' Retrieved 11 February 2011.</ref>
Demonstrators began to gather at new locations in Cairo. The army also surrounded the presidential palace and state television and radio buildings<ref name="aljazlive" /> as protesters surrounded the Egyptian radio and television union building demanding fair media coverage from state television. The state television shifted its attitude towards the protesters and begun referring to them as Jan25 Youth Revolution<!--is this precise?-->, admitting mistakes had been made in the media coverage of the protests: "We [the state TV] were under an information chaos," the news anchor stated. "We had strict orders from external sides."{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} There were also major protests in Alexandria and Mansoura. In [[Arish]], in north Sinai, the second police station in 24 hours came under heavy arms fire â including RPGs â in which at least one protester<!--need to add to total tally--> was killed and 20 injured, with possibly more police fatalities.<ref name="aljazlive" />
Demonstrators began to gather at new locations in Cairo. The army also surrounded the presidential palace and state television and radio buildings<ref name="aljazlive" /> as protesters surrounded the Egyptian radio and television union building demanding fair media coverage from state television. The state television shifted its attitude towards the protesters and begun referring to them as Jan25 Youth Revolution<!--is this precise?-->, admitting mistakes had been made in the media coverage of the protests: "We [the state TV] were under an information chaos," the news anchor stated. "We had strict orders from external sides."{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} There were also major protests in Alexandria and Mansoura. In [[Arish]], in north Sinai, the second police station in 24 hours came under heavy arms fire â including RPGs â in which at least one protester<!--need to add to total tally--> was killed and 20 injured, with possibly more police fatalities.<ref name="aljazlive" />
Line 468: Line 468:
Mubarak and his family reportedly left Cairo for the calmer Red Sea resort of [[Sharm el-Sheikh]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110211/D9LAK12O0.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak in Red Sea resort as protests rage |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Former Finance Minister [[Youssef Boutros Ghali]] fled Egypt to [[Beirut]].<ref name="ahram1">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/5408/Egypt/Politics-/Youssef-Boutros-Ghali-leaves-Egypt.aspx |title=Youssef Boutros Ghali leaves Egypt - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
Mubarak and his family reportedly left Cairo for the calmer Red Sea resort of [[Sharm el-Sheikh]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110211/D9LAK12O0.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak in Red Sea resort as protests rage |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Former Finance Minister [[Youssef Boutros Ghali]] fled Egypt to [[Beirut]].<ref name="ahram1">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/5408/Egypt/Politics-/Youssef-Boutros-Ghali-leaves-Egypt.aspx |title=Youssef Boutros Ghali leaves Egypt - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
â
======Celebration======
  â
[[File:Protesters with soldier.jpg|thumb|200px|left|A soldier joins the protesters in celebration of Mubarak's downfall.]]
 
{{Rquote|right|The people of Egypt have spoken, their voices have been heard, and Egypt will never be the same.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Obama: Egypt Will Never Be The Same|last=Klein|first=Kent|publisher=''Voanews.com''|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Obama-Egypt-Will-Never-Be-the-Same-115965119.html|date=11/2/11|accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>|[[Barack Obama]], United States president}}
{{Rquote|right|The people of Egypt have spoken, their voices have been heard, and Egypt will never be the same.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Obama: Egypt Will Never Be The Same|last=Klein|first=Kent|publisher=''Voanews.com''|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Obama-Egypt-Will-Never-Be-the-Same-115965119.html|date=11/2/11|accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>|[[Barack Obama]], United States president}}

Mubarak's resignation was followed by nationwide celebrations.<ref name="ahram1"/> [[File:Celebratory protesters.jpg|thumb|Egyptians in Giza celebrate Mubarak's resignation.]]
+
  +
======Celebration======
  +
[[File:Celebratory protesters.jpg|thumb|Egyptians in Giza celebrate Mubarak's resignation.]]
  +
Mubarak's resignation was followed by nationwide celebrations.<ref name="ahram1"/>
  +
[[Mohammed ElBaradei]] told the ''Associated Press'' "This is the greatest day of my life. The country has been liberated after decades of repression," and he expects a "beautiful" transition of power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110211/D9LAM4LO0.html |title=Mubarak resigns, hands power to military |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Mohammed El Baradei said that "Egypt is free."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1618774.php/ElBaradei-Egypt-is-a-free-and-proud-nation-Extra |title=ElBaradei: Egypt is a free and proud nation (Extra) |publisher=Monsters and Critics |date=2010-11-17 |accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref> Various media outlets pointed out that this date was also the anniversary of the [[Islamic Revolution]], which occurred on 11 February 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/news/iran-congratulates-egyptian-people-s-victory-news-international-lcmcacigiid.html |title=Iran congratulates Egyptian people's 'victory' |publisher=Sify.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref>
[[Mohammed ElBaradei]] told the ''Associated Press'' "This is the greatest day of my life. The country has been liberated after decades of repression," and he expects a "beautiful" transition of power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110211/D9LAM4LO0.html |title=Mubarak resigns, hands power to military |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Mohammed El Baradei said that "Egypt is free."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1618774.php/ElBaradei-Egypt-is-a-free-and-proud-nation-Extra |title=ElBaradei: Egypt is a free and proud nation (Extra) |publisher=Monsters and Critics |date=2010-11-17 |accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref> Various media outlets pointed out that this date was also the anniversary of the [[Islamic Revolution]], which occurred on 11 February 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/news/iran-congratulates-egyptian-people-s-victory-news-international-lcmcacigiid.html |title=Iran congratulates Egyptian people's 'victory' |publisher=Sify.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref>
